awd_titl_txt: RI: Small: Anytime Algorithms and Bounds for Probabilistic Graphical Models
awd_abstract_narration:
Probabilistic graphical models are employed throughout science and engineering to solve difficult problems, including automated reasoning and decision making, computer vision, computational biology and genetics, and data mining.  However, exact inference is often computationally intractable, necessitating approximations or bounds.  While significant progress has been made, many real-world problems remain out of reach. Many techniques require a set of problem-specific customizations and choices that must be made in advance, with little guidance or automation. Our research will both improve the performance of probabilistic graphical models and will make these techniques more widely available. The investigators support education and diversity through their undergraduate and graduate teaching, and through making their software available to researchers and to the public.

The goal of this research is to develop the next generation of approximate, anytime inference techniques and algorithms for graphical models. Informed by the framework of heuristic search, the investigators will create improved unified schemes for message-passing, vibrational and sampling algorithms. These new algorithms seek to effectively manage models containing mixtures of probabilistic and deterministic relationships, as well as both graph-based and context-specific independence relationships. They will provide meaningful bounds on the results and the accuracy of the algorithms, while simplifying or automating any required tuning to the problem instance, optimizing the inherent trade-offs between complexity and accuracy. The algorithms will be extended to the most challenging tasks (i.e., max-sum-product tasks) such as maximum expected utility queries for optimal decision-making. The investigators will collaborate with domain experts to apply their algorithms to applications such as planning and computational protein design.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The supported research developed approximation algorithms for probabilistic reasoning that can be applied automatically and adaptively in an anytime manner, while also providing guidance on the resulting approximation quality.   We focus on the framework of Probabilistic graphical models  which uses directed graphs to show how different pieces of information are related. This includes Bayesian networks  that can update  beliefs based on new evidence, and influence diagrams, which allows computing optimal decisions by considering potential outcomes and rewards.  As models of interest grow, the exponentially increasing cost of inference, or answering questions from the model, becomes prohibitive. This effect is particularly difficult in “mixed” inference tasks, appearing in Influence diagrams such as when there is both something to optimized over (a decision or policy, or a design) in which the objective involves computing a summation (such as an expectation or marginal probability). We refer to these as “max-sum” tasks.

We developed and studied several novel methods for max-sum tasks with significant improvements over existing methodologies.  In particular for the max-sum task for generating  optimal policies,  we developed variational message-passing algorithms (i.e.,  weighted mini-bucket augmented with cost-shifting) that when combined with exponential representation of utilities, yielded upper and lower bounds that are far tighter than state of the art. For pure summation questions  (e.g., belief updating or computing the probability of evidence) our  abstraction sampling, algorithm combines variational approximations with stratified Monte Carlo sampling to provide state-of-the-art performance. Another method, UFO, combines constraint processing with variational bounds to improve scalability in problems such as computational protein design. We integrated machine learning techniques to improve approximation quality: NeuroBE uses learning to tractably approximate difficult inference problems, and EM4CI uses learning to answer queries about the effect of causal interventions.  In addition to research publications, we developed and disseminated teaching materials and gave presentations and tutorials.
